result.execSummary:
Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.
result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Jay Edward Smith

records.addlTxt:
11:10 AM Defendant Jay Edward Smith in court, in custody.  Attorney Lance Morgan Nelsen in court for Jay Edward Smith.  Attorney Angela M Wilson in court for State of Wisconsin. State recites agreement that 22CF307 be dismissed but read in. For 22CF304 for count 1 a deferred judgment of conviction for 2 years. For Count 2, 9 months jail imposed and stayed for 2 years probatin. Conditions of probation include serve 75 days with credit for 75 days, comply with all programming as deemed necessary by the Dept of Corrections to include domestic violence programming and pay a $20 fine plus costs. For Count 3, 60 days jail imposed and stayed for 2 years probation. Conditions of probation include serve 75 days with credit for 75 days and comply with all programming as deemed necessary by the Dept of Corrections to include domestic violence programming. Restitution to remain open for 60 days. State has complied with Victim's Rights. Defendant pleads no contest. Attorney Nelsen stipulates to a factual basis. Court accepts the Defendant's plea and finds that the Defendant's plea has been freely, voluntarily and intelligently made. The Defendant understands all the rights he is waiving by his plea. The Defendant is found guilty and Judgment of Conviction is entered.

Court defers an entry judgment of conviction for 2 years on Count 1 in 22CF304. In 22CF304,for Count 2, 9 months jail imposed and stayed for 2 years probation. Conditions of probation include serve 75 days with credit for 75 days, comply with all programming as deemed necessary by the Dept of Corrections to include domestic violence programming and pay a $20 fine plus costs. For Count 3, 60 days jail imposed and stayed for 2 years probation. If revoked, consecutive to Count 2 and any other sentence. Conditions of probation include serve 75 days with credit for 75 days and comply with all programming as deemed necessary by the Dept of Corrections to include domestic violence programming. Restitution to remain open for 60 days. 22CF307 is dismissed but read in.

10:30 AM Defendant Jay Edward Smith in court, in custody.  Attorney Lance Morgan Nelsen in court for Jay Edward Smith.  Attorney Angela M Wilson in court for State of Wisconsin. Court calls cases 22CF304 and 22CF307. Attorney acknowledges receipt of the information in both files, waives a formal reading, enters a plea of not guilty and requests a status in both files. Attorney Nelsen notes receipt of an offer that contemplates a DJOC. Asks for a status next week. State is in agreement.
Status conference scheduled for October 31, 2022 at 11:00 am.
Exhibit 1 from preliminary hearing - certified bail/bond form from case 22CF304
State's Demand for Discovery and Inspection

10:45Defendant Jay Edward Smith in court, in custody.  Attorney Lance Morgan Nelsen in court for Jay Edward Smith. Prosecuting attorney Allison E. Cogbill in court for the State of Wisconsin. 
State- Officer witness is not present, requests prelim be reset
Att Nelsen- If no waiver was made would object to rescheduling
Court- was a waiver on 8/22/22
Att Nelsen- waiver was to procure counsel, he has accomplished that, would not agree to reset prelim
Court questions State's efforts to secure witness
State- sent notice to witness on 8/22/22, tried to call when he didn't appear this morning.
Court- Defendant has another case, will be back in court next week for prelim on that case. rescheduling would not prejudice defendant, Notes witnesses should be served as per statute, not sent notice, does not qualify as proper subpoena for witness. Sets new date
Preliminary hearing scheduled for September 14, 2022 at 09:00 am.
